snippet.textDisplay: Paradise killer's is not an allegory for capitalism it's an allegory for communism and the way make slaves out of the lesser classes.
snippet.textOriginal: Paradise killer's is not an allegory for capitalism it's an allegory for communism and the way make slaves out of the lesser classes.

snippet.textDisplay:
Not sure how you figured that bud.
Oli Clarke Smith, co-founder of Kaizen Game Works and creative director on Paradise Killer:
"The game has anti-capitalist, anti-establishment system, and anti-discrimination themes."
"Obviously the modern world has a very explicit slavery problem but it can also be more insidious. We are all under the yoke of debt and capitalism. The elite try to create an illusion that this is what happiness is but the horrors of modern society are plain to see all around us."
"Vaporwave has an anti-capitalist energy and intent that punk could never have as bands had to sell records in a capitalist marketplace with the blessing of record companies....We believe very strongly that the world is broken. Capitalism and religion donâ€™t work, governments have failed society and people are in pain. It is important to remember that in Paradise Killer, you are one of the bad guys. The Syndicate are trying to resurrect alien gods that want to drown the universe in a sea of blood. The gods exist only to satisfy their own whims, much like the wealthy and powerful in our own society. By embracing vaporwave aesthetics and themes we can shine a critical light on the Syndicate and thus hold a mirror up to our own society without being preachy to the player."

snippet.textDisplay: Love the art I'm seeing here. Reminds me ever so slightly of Abyss Odyssey. The art style is different (uh... South American Art Nouveau?), but together with the character concepts it jumped a spark. Eldritch horror but whimsical, and so casual that it can become almost-but-not-quite familiar.
snippet.textOriginal: Love the art I'm seeing here. Reminds me ever so slightly of Abyss Odyssey. The art style is different (uh... snippet.textDisplay:
I love that when henry tells lady love dies that THEY are the bad guys, she just seems like... unable to process it, like the mere suggestion that her lifestyle is fundamentally evil just... doesnt register.
What finally hammered the idea that LLD is a bad person is how she killed her two best friends in thousands of years, and her reactions didnt went beyond "you souldnt had done that haha now Im going to walk everywhere or drive the car myself"

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved this video. I just played the console release of Paradise Killer and was profoundly affected by it. So I found myself looking for a good video essay and found yours. Any video that makes me read Ursula K. Le Guin already grabs my attention, but it also unlocked the memory that I'd read this story back in middle school. I'd forgotten the name of the story or the author, but I never forgot the premise that a lone child was suffering for the greater good of their community...

Anyway, I thought your video was up there in quality with the YouTubers who have hundreds of thousands of subscribers. I look forward to watching more of your videos and I hope that your channel, like Paradise Killer, gets the recognition it deserves.
snippet.textOriginal:
I loved this video.  I just played the console release of Paradise Killer and was profoundly affected by it.  So I found myself looking for a good video essay and found yours.  Any video that makes me read Ursula K. Le Guin already grabs my attention, but it also unlocked the memory that I'd read this story back in middle school.  I'd forgotten the name of the story or the author, but I never forgot the premise that a lone child was suffering for the greater good of their community...

Anyway, I thought your video was up there in quality with the YouTubers who have hundreds of thousands of subscribers.  I look forward to watching more of your videos and I hope that your channel, like Paradise Killer, gets the recognition it deserves.

snippet.textDisplay: very glad i came across this video, finally gave me true closure on the game. played it almost two years ago, without a doubt one of my most favourite detective games, the freedom of investigation it gives you is fantastic, but i could never shake the feeling that the ending was just uninspired. as i went through the trial i was waiting for that "ok so when do i get to dismantle the syndicate? the ghosts, henry and shinji make it pretty obvious the syndicate is not great and i agree with them" moment, but no, there's no turnaround, no real victory to speak of. your video made me understand that it wasn't laziness on the writers' part, that was the intended outcome, the return of the status quo. my mistake was in misreading love dies's character: i may not believe that this paradise is worth it but she's team syndicate all the way, not even the (potential) loss of her friends who just wanted out is enough to sway her.
snippet.textOriginal: very glad i came across this video, finally gave me true closure on the game. played it almost two years ago, without a doubt one of my most favourite detective games, the freedom of investigation it gives you is fantastic, but i could never shake the feeling that the ending was just uninspired. as i went through the trial i was waiting for that "ok so when do i get to dismantle the syndicate? the ghosts, henry and shinji make it pretty obvious the syndicate is not great and i agree with them" moment, but no, there's no turnaround, no real victory to speak of. your video made me understand that it wasn't laziness on the writers' part, that was the intended outcome, the return of the status quo. my mistake was in misreading love dies's character: i may not believe that this paradise is worth it but she's team syndicate all the way, not even the (potential) loss of her friends who just wanted out is enough to sway her.

snippet.textDisplay: It would have been so easy for them to create a comforting ending where the system is destroyed and the slaves are freed, but the devs withheld that and I love them so much for it :) Glad you got something out of the video!
snippet.textOriginal: It would have been so easy for them to create a comforting ending where the system is destroyed and the slaves are freed, but the devs withheld that and I love them so much for it :) Glad you got something out of the video!

snippet.textDisplay: Saw this game on PS Plus, finished it in a day with all evidence and everything necessary. Stayed up all night. Seriously, love it so much. I was also a sucker for Touch Detective and CrimeLabs growing up, but I cannot find any other game like this. It was so different and really hope the game developers are working on something else!
snippet.textOriginal: Saw this game on PS Plus, finished it in a day with all evidence and everything necessary. Stayed up all night. Seriously, love it so much. I was also a sucker for Touch Detective and CrimeLabs growing up, but I cannot find any other game like this. It was so different and really hope the game developers are working on something else!

snippet.textDisplay: This is the first video I've seen on this channel and I'm looking forward to checking out more! Something I think it worth noting about the doomed cycles of paradise is that the Syndicate already know Perfect 25 won't be successful either. There are literally in-game conversations about it. But they can't or won't do anything about it. They'd rather pretend that everything will somehow turn out right next time than address the problems they're fully aware of.
snippet.textOriginal: This is the first video I've seen on this channel and I'm looking forward to checking out more! Something I think it worth noting about the doomed cycles of paradise is that the Syndicate already *know* Perfect 25 won't be successful either. There are literally in-game conversations about it. But they can't or won't do anything about it. They'd rather pretend that everything will somehow turn out right next time than address the problems they're fully aware of.

snippet.textDisplay:
can't decide if talking about spiritual death of mice to a freaking Rain World soundtrack is hilarious or disturbing (because, of course, Rain World also talks about "spiritual death" but in a very different way)

Both mouse experiment and literary 'utopias' seem to be consistently missing that we really need something to live for, and turns out even mice need their life to be intresting and fulfilling. Is it a christian thing, comfort is inherently sinful so all our brains revolve around finding new ways to justify that?Â 

A box with mice and food is NOT an utopia. In no way it discredits the idea of post-scarcity, or somehow proves inherent immorality of comfort, or automatically makes every win a zero-sum.

I remember a short story by Greg Egan about a woman in a post-scarcity society somewhere in endless "New Territories". it her took thousand of years to find friends she trusted enough to talk about her fear of swimming. That's just a small slice, but perhaps a more honest approach to the Utopia.

I remember a short story by Greg Egan about a woman in a post-scarcity society somewhere in endless "New Territories". it her took thousand of years to find friends she trusted enough to talk about her fear of swimming. That's just a small slice, but perhaps a more honest approach to the Utopia.
